phases.description: Foundational interpretive principles that prioritize the statutory text itself. Applied in every case as the initial interpretive layer.

canons.name: Supremacy-of-Text
canons.explanation_short: Text controls; meaning derives from enacted words in context.
canons.explanation_full: The words of a governing text are of paramount concern, and what they convey, in their context, is what the text means. Purpose sheds light only on deciding which of various textually permissible meanings should be adopted.
operational_logic: Identify all linguistically permissible readings of the disputed provision.
If only one reading is consistent with syntax and grammar, adopt it.
Reject policy-driven alternatives unless textually permissible.

canons.name: Whole-Text
canons.explanation_short: Interpret provisions in light of the entire statute.
canons.explanation_full: The text must be construed as a whole. 'In ascertaining the plain meaning of the statute, the court must look to the particular statutory language at issue, as well as the language and design of the statute as a whole.' The meaning of a statute is to be looked for, not in any single section, but in all the parts together and in their relation to the end in view.
operational_logic: Analyze related sections and definitions within the statute.
Resolve conflicts by harmonizing the language with the statute's structure.
Reject interpretations that make other sections redundant or meaningless.

canons.name: Harmonious-Reading
canons.explanation_short: Provisions should be read in harmony, not conflict.
canons.explanation_full: The provisions of a text should be interpreted in a way that renders them compatible, not contradictory. The imperative of harmony among provisions is more categorical than most other canons of construction because it is invariably true that intelligent drafters do not contradict themselves.
operational_logic: Check if competing interpretations create internal contradictions.
Prefer interpretations that allow all provisions to coexist meaningfully.
Declare conflict only if irreconcilable after all harmonization attempts.

canons.name: Presumption-of-Consistent-Usage
canons.explanation_short: Same word = same meaning; different words = different meaning.
canons.explanation_full: A word or phrase is presumed to bear the same meaning throughout a text; a material variation in terms suggests a variation in meaning. It is by no means a correct rule of interpretation to construe the same word in the same sense, wherever it occurs in the same instrument: their meaning is controlled by context.
operational_logic: Identify repeated terms across the statute.
Presume uniform meaning unless context compels otherwise.
If terms differ, presume deliberate differentiation in meaning.

phases.description: Canons for resolving linguistic ambiguity by clarifying ordinary sense, interpretive principles, and historical meaning.

canons.name: Interpretation Principle
canons.explanation_full: No text applies itself; interpretation is always required. Meaning does not leap from the page without a process of reasoning. This canon establishes that interpretation is not optional but intrinsic to legal application.
operational_logic: Affirm that legal text requires interpretive analysis before enforcement.
Document reasoning steps to ensure transparency and consistency.

canons.name: Ordinary Meaning
canons.explanation_short: Words are understood in their ordinary sense unless context dictates otherwise.
canons.explanation_full: Words are to be understood in their ordinary, everyday meaningsâ€”unless the context indicates that they bear a technical sense. When text deals with a specialized subject, the expected meaning aligns with that discipline's usage.
operational_logic: Default to everyday meaning of disputed terms.
If statute concerns a specialized domain (e.g., medical, legal), prefer technical usage.
Verify ordinary meaning using authoritative dictionaries or contemporary usage at enactment.

canons.name: Fixed Meaning
canons.explanation_short: Words mean what they did when adopted.
canons.explanation_full: The meaning of a legal text is fixed at the time of its enactment. Later usage, evolving norms, or contemporary preferences do not alter the original sense unless the text itself provides for dynamic application.
operational_logic: Identify the date of enactment.
Confirm the ordinary or technical meaning as understood at that time.
Reject post-enactment shifts in common usage unless the text explicitly anticipates evolution.

phases.description: Canons for resolving ambiguity by analyzing structure, syntax, and logical relationships within the text.

canons.name: Negative Implication
canons.explanation_short: Expressing one thing implies exclusion of others.
canons.explanation_full: The expression of one thing implies the exclusion of others (expressio unius est exclusio alterius). When a law specifies certain things, the natural inference is that omissions were intentional. This canon must be applied cautiously, since context can negate the implication.
operational_logic: Identify enumerations or lists in the statute.
If a specific list is provided without catch-all terms, presume exclusion of unlisted items.
Override this presumption if context indicates non-exhaustive intent.

canons.name: Mandatory/Permissive
canons.explanation_full: Mandatory words impose a duty; permissive words grant discretion. Traditionally, 'shall' means mandatory and 'may' means discretionaryâ€”though drafting sloppiness and modern conventions can blur the distinction. Courts generally enforce the mandatory-permissive dichotomy unless context clearly dictates otherwise.
operational_logic: Detect modal verbs: 'shall', 'must', 'may'.
If 'shall' or 'must', interpret as creating a mandatory obligation.
If 'may', interpret as granting permission unless context indicates duty.

canons.name: Conjunctive/Disjunctive
canons.explanation_full: 'And' joins terms conjunctively; 'or' joins terms disjunctively. Negatives, plurals, and variant phrasing complicate interpretation, but the default presumption applies absent strong contrary context.
operational_logic: Check if listed conditions use 'and' or 'or'.
If 'and', assume all conditions apply together (cumulative).
If 'or', assume any one condition suffices (alternative).
Account for negatives or syntactic anomalies that reverse these defaults.

canons.name: Ejusdem Generis
canons.explanation_short: General terms after specifics are limited to the same kind.
canons.explanation_full: When a general term follows an enumeration of specifics, it is construed to embrace only items of the same kind or class. The rationale: if drafters intended unlimited breadth, they would have omitted the specifics.
operational_logic: Detect enumerations followed by a general term (e.g., 'other').
Infer class from the specifics listed (e.g., vehicles â†’ cars, trucks).
Restrict general term to that class unless context negates the presumption.

canons.name: Series Qualifier
canons.explanation_short: Modifier applies to the whole series unless context says otherwise.
canons.explanation_full: When there is a straightforward, parallel construction involving nouns or verbs in a series, a prepositive or postpositive modifier normally applies to the entire series unless syntax or repeated determiners suggest otherwise.
operational_logic: Identify modifiers positioned before or after a series.
Apply modifier to the whole list unless repeated articles or syntax indicate a narrower reach.
Flag ambiguity if series structure is inconsistent or uses mixed determiners.

phases.description: Apply override canons to adjust interpretation scores where ambiguity persists after structural analysis.

canons.name: Presumption Against Ineffectiveness
canons.explanation_short: Favor interpretations that make the statute operative.
canons.explanation_full: A textually permissible interpretation that furthers rather than obstructs the documentâ€™s purpose should be favored. This canon aims to avoid constructions that render provisions inoperative or nonsensical.
operational_logic: Detect interpretations that nullify or severely limit the statute.
Apply +40 if interpretation sustains statuteâ€™s core function.

canons.name: Absurdity Doctrine
canons.explanation_short: Avoid interpretations that lead to absurd results.
canons.explanation_full: A provision may be disregarded or judicially corrected if its plain application produces a result so irrational that no reasonable person could approve. Applies narrowly to prevent gross drafting errors or nonsensical outcomes.
operational_logic: Identify interpretation consequences flagged as irrational.
Apply -50 to interpretations producing absurdity.

canons.name: Constitutional Avoidance
canons.explanation_short: Choose reading that avoids constitutional doubts.
canons.explanation_full: A statute should be construed to avoid placing its constitutionality in doubt. Courts should adopt a plausible interpretation that avoids serious constitutional problems.
operational_logic: Flag interpretations that would raise constitutional conflicts.
Apply +40 to interpretations reducing constitutional risk.

canons.name: Rule of Lenity
canons.explanation_short: Ambiguity in criminal law favors the defendant.
canons.explanation_full: Ambiguity in a statute defining a crime or penalty must be resolved in favor of the defendant. This protects due process and separation of powers principles.
operational_logic: If statute is criminal and ambiguity persists, boost lenient reading.
Apply +50 adjustment.

canons.name: Presumption Against Retroactivity
canons.explanation_full: Statutes are presumed to apply only prospectively, not retroactively, unless clear text says otherwise. This protects reliance interests and legal stability.
operational_logic: Detect interpretations applying statute to pre-enactment conduct.
Apply -60 penalty unless text explicitly authorizes retroactivity.
